article.headline: Pellot-Rosa's FT with 1.6 seconds left the difference
article.linkText: Va. Commonwealth earns first NCAA berth since '96
article.story: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) -- Jesse Pellot-Rosa was feeling like a hero, yet not too proud to reveal the emotions he felt on the foul line. "I'd be lying if I told ya'll I wasn't nervous," the freshman walk-on said after his second free throw with 1.6 seconds to play gave Virginia Commonwealth a 55-54 victory against George Mason in the Colonial Athletic Association championship Monday night, and a spot in the NCAA Tournament. The first try clanged off the back of the rim. "After I missed the first free throw, I was like, `This game's not going to overtime.' I knew I had to make the second one," he said. When he did, the partisan crowd at Richmond Coliseum -- silenced by the Patriots' late rally -- erupted, almost prematurely. The Patriots got one last chance, but Jai Lewis' open fallaway 12-footer missed completely. "I was nervous. I thought the shot was good," VCU's Troy Godwin said. "But I thought if I was nervous, he had to be nervous to take the shot." Lewis said he was open, but so deep the backboard was in his way. "I think it was a pretty good look," Lewis said of the attempt from the left side. "I shot it a little long. Maybe next time I'll get that." The Rams (23-7) earned their first CAA title since 1996 -- their debut season in the league -- and their seventh trip to the tournament overall. For coach Jeff Capel, at 29 the youngest Division I head coach, the victory also will mark a return to the field of 65. As a four-year starter at Duke in the mid- to late 1990s, the NCAA tournament was almost a given. "This is awesome,' Capel said. "It's different because at Duke, it was expected. You just kind of expected it and if you didn't get to the Final Four, it was a huge disappointment. This is huge for us. This is probably a little bit sweeter because I'm not sure if anyone expected us to do it." The way the top-seeded Rams did it was sweet, too. They led almost the entire way until Tony Skinn's 3-pointer tied it with 9 seconds to play. Without calling time, they pushed the ball up the court. Pellot-Rosa eventually took it hard to the basket and drew the foul from Lewis. The crowd screamed with delight when officials whistled the foul, then groaned and grew eerily silent when Pellot-Rosa's first free throw missed. The swish brought an eruption that Lewis' shot almost killed. Finally able to relax later, Domonic Jones sighed with relief. "It's really hard to describe right now," said the CAA player of the year, who led VCU with 13 points. "When you work so hard for something and it comes down and you finally get it, it's that much sweeter." George Mason (21-9) fell just short of its third championship in six years and fourth overall, but not before a stirring rally. VCU's Michael Doles, who had five points in the last 3:17, grabbed an airball from Jones and hit a running banker with 1:10 to play, giving VCU a 54-49 lead. But Lewis scored inside with 51.8 seconds left and Skinn, a hero of the semifinals when he scored 27 points, followed two misses by VCU by hitting the rainbow 3-pointer over Jones, getting the Patriots even. George Mason had trailed since midway through the first half. "We needed to catch one break," Patriots coach Jim Larranaga said. Instead, the last one went to the Rams. "This is just a very special day for VCU," Capel said.
